description.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of individuals in Central African Governments, NGOs, and Wildlife/Forestry Colleges in Results-based Management

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to train coaches who can assist teams to design, implement, and monitor effective conservation projects using results-based management for their conservation work in Central Africa. The project will: 1) increase conservation planning capacity in Central Africa by strengthening the capacity of 20 ""coaches"" in the region to facilitate biodiversity conservation project planning with various teams using the Open Standards. Conservation planning capacity activities include hosting a four-day coaches training and providing follow up support. 2) Institutionalize an Open Standards module at Mbalmayo Forestry School and Garoua Wildlife College in Cameroon to build conservation planning capacity (for protected area management and species conservation) of students at the start of their conservation careers. Open Standards Module activities include: teaching the pilot module, working with faculty at Mbalmayo and Garoua to build in-house capacity to teach/coach the Open Standards and institutionalize the Open Standards into the Colleges' curriculum.."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Chinko Project, 2013/14 Anti-Poaching Program: Building Capacity

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to establish a wildlife conservation effort in the Chinko Project area, a 17,000 square kilometer wooded savanna and forest zone in southeast Central African Republic. Specific activities include: (1) train, equip, and support at least six teams of private sector, anti-poaching rangers; and (2) conduct participative workshops and informational sessions with seasonal livestock herders and local community members to build support for future conservation efforts.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This grant supports the longest running study of African forest elephants at Dzanga Bai in the Central Africa Republic. In spite of political turmoil and instability in the country, the area remains an important habitat and gathering site for large numbers of elephants. Funds support ongoing surveillance and monitoring of the site, collection of baseline data, and collaboration with the Dzanga-Sangha project in anti-poaching efforts.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Preliminary Assessment of the Chinko Conservation Area

description.narrative: This project enables African Parks Foundation to investigate the feasibility of taking on the management of the Chinko Conservation Area in the Central Africa Republic. The Chinko Conservation Areas has some of the last remaining wildlife populations in the Shahelo-Guinean transition landscapes even though it has been severely affected by nomadic transborder poaching incidents. Specific activities include: 1) site visitation and meeting with stakeholders, 2) aerial surveillance of Chinko area and periphery.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: This project enables African Parks Foundation to investigate the feasibility of taking on the management of the Chinko Conservation Area in the Central Africa Republic. The Chinko Conservation Areas has some of the last remaining wildlife populations in the Shahelo-Guinean transition landscapes even though it has been severely affected by nomadic transborder poaching incidents. Specific activities include: 1) site visitation and meeting with stakeholders, 2) aerial surveillance of Chinko area and periphery.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Creating an evidence-base for developing and evaluating interventions to reduce unsustainable bushmeat hunting in Central Africa

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to advance our understanding of the effectiveness of efforts that address the impact of the commercial bushmeat trade by improving the tools and evidence available to design and evaluate interventions. Specific activities include: (1) development of an open-access database of bushmeat hunting, trade and consumption, and interventions; (2) development of performance indicators and methods to better monitor bushmeat use at local, national, and regional-levels; and (3) participation and technical assistance in regional and international policy meetings to promote the available evidence on the effectiveness of relevant bushmeat law and policy.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Sustainable Nature Management of the Chinko Project Area (CPA) in the Central African Republic.

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to support a conservation effort in the Chinko Reserve of the Central African Republic by developing the necessary infrastructure, law enforcement activities, and wildlife monitoring and habitat management to support park management. The project is intended to conserve the rich savanna and forest species of the Chinko/Mbari drainage basin including large antelopes, wild dogs, leopard, and elephants by addressing the impacts of poaching, bushmeat, human wildlife conflict, mining and security threats. Specific activities include: (1) road construction to demarcate boundaries and enable patrols, (2) development of scout housing to accommodate the law enforcement team, (3) purchase of supplies to facilitate communications..."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN CENTRAL AFRICA BY DEVELOPING A NEW GENERATION OF RESEARCHERS TO ADDRESS CRITICAL CONSERVATION CHALLENGES FACING WILDLIFE, BIODIVERSITY

description.narrative: Funds under this award are to be used to support.conservation efforts in Central Africa by developing a new generation of researchers to address .critical.conservation challenges facing wildlife, biodiversity and ecosystem health. The project is intended .to conserve wildlife and habitats by addressing capacity development needs, specifically research .support for graduate students and early career professionals in the Congo Basin. Specific .activities include: (1) providing support for applied wildlife research via a competitive process; .and (2) providing assistance for early career Central African researchers to position them for .future success in wildlife conservation.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN CENTRAL AFRICA BY DEVELOPING A NEW GENERATION OF RESEARCHERS TO ADDRESS CRITICAL CONSERVATION CHALLENGES FACING WILDLIFE, BIODIVERSITY

description.narrative: The project is intended to conserve wildlife and habitats by addressing capacity development needs, specifically research support for graduate students and early career professionals in the Congo Basin. Specific activities include: (1) providing support for applied wildlife research via a competitive process; and (2) providing assistance for early career Central African researchers to position them for future success in wildlife conservation.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Enhancing passive acoustic monitoring in the Congo Basin

description.narrative: The purpose of this two-year project is to use acoustic recording devices to provide information about imperiled forest elephants that are very costly to monitor by direct observation or traditional transects. These funds will support (1) a monitoring program at the Dzanga Bai, a forest clearing in Central African Republic and an important source of wildlife management data as the site of the worlds longest running individual-based study of African forest elephants; and (2) a regional program to link and improve the science of biologists and field technicians using acoustic monitoring for wildlife management in Africa.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry
